home.title: PolarCraft
home.subtitle: Polarized Light Physics Puzzle Game
home.description: An educational voxel puzzle game based on real polarization physics principles. Explore Malus's Law, birefringence, interference and more through interactive 3D puzzles.
home.gameDescription: Solve puzzles using polarized light beams and optical components
home.courseDescription: Learn polarization physics through interactive demonstrations

hints.vision: Press V to toggle polarized vision
hints.camera: Press C to change camera mode

0.name: Light and Gate
0.description: Match the emitter's polarization angle with the sensor to activate it
hints: Press R to rotate the emitter's polarization angle
Match the emitter's polarization with the sensor (both 0°)
The sensor activates when light with matching polarization reaches it

1.name: Polarizer
1.description: Use the polarizer to filter light and activate the sensor
hints: Place a polarizer between the emitter and sensor
Try different angles to see how intensity changes

2.name: Malus's Law
2.description: Use two polarizers to control light intensity
hints: Two perpendicular polarizers block all light
Add a third polarizer at 45° in between to let some light through
This demonstrates the principle of polarization rotation

3.name: Wave Plate
3.description: Use the rotator to change polarization direction without losing intensity
hints: The rotator changes polarization angle by 45° or 90°
Press R to switch between rotation amounts
Unlike polarizers, rotators preserve light intensity

4.name: Birefringence
4.description: Use the splitter to create two beams with different polarizations
hints: The splitter (calcite) creates o-ray (0°) and e-ray (90°)
Both sensors need to be activated to complete the level
Birefringence is used in many optical instruments

basics.description: Fundamental concepts of light and waves

1.title: Polarization Modulation & Measurement
1.description: Understanding polarization states and their manipulation

2.title: Interface Reflection Polarization
2.description: How polarization changes at material interfaces

4.title: Turbid Media Polarization
4.description: Light scattering and polarization in turbid media

polarizationState.title: Polarization State & Wave Synthesis
polarizationState.description: Wave synthesis produces different polarization states: linear, circular, elliptical

physics.principle: Polarization state is determined by the amplitude ratio and phase difference of two orthogonal electric field components
details: When δ=0° or 180°, it is linearly polarized
When δ=90° and Ex=Ey, it is circularly polarized

experiment.title: Polarization State Conversion Experiment
experiment.example: Using wave plates to convert linear polarization to circular polarization
details: Quarter-wave plate converts 45° linear polarization to circular
Half-wave plate rotates linear polarization direction
Liquid crystals can electrically control polarization conversion

frontier.title: Quantum Optics & Communication
details: Single photon polarization for quantum communication

malus.title: Malus's Law
malus.description: Intensity change when polarized light passes through a polarizer: I = I₀ × cos²(θ)

physics.principle: Malus's Law describes the intensity change when polarized light passes through a polarizer
details: θ is the angle between light polarization and polarizer axis

experiment.title: Polarizer Combination Experiment
experiment.example: Two polarizers to verify Malus's Law
details: Rotate analyzer to measure transmitted intensity

frontier.title: LCD Display Technology
details: Liquid crystal molecules control polarization rotation
Combined with polarizers to modulate brightness
Widely used in phones, TVs, and monitors

birefringence.title: Birefringence Effect
birefringence.description: Crystals like calcite split one beam into ordinary (o) and extraordinary (e) rays

physics.principle: Birefringent crystals split incident light into ordinary ray (o-ray) and extraordinary ray (e-ray)
details: O-ray and e-ray have perpendicular polarization directions
Different propagation speeds cause phase difference
Calcite is a typical birefringent material

experiment.title: Calcite Double Image Observation
experiment.example: Viewing text through calcite produces double images
details: Rotating the crystal: one image stays fixed, one rotates
Polarizers can eliminate either image individually
Can measure the birefringence of the crystal

frontier.title: Polarization Optical Components
details: Used to make high-precision polarizing beam splitters

waveplate.title: Wave Plate Principle
waveplate.description: Quarter-wave and half-wave plates' effect on polarization states

physics.principle: Wave plates introduce controlled phase delay using birefringence
details: Can convert linear to circular polarization or rotate polarization direction

experiment.title: Wave Plate Polarization Conversion
experiment.example: Using wave plates to produce different polarization states
details: λ/2 plate rotates polarization direction by 2θ
Combined wave plates can produce any polarization state

frontier.title: 3D Movies & VR Displays
details: Left and right eye images use opposite circular polarizations
Circular polarizing glasses separate left/right images

fresnel.title: Fresnel Equations
fresnel.description: Reflection/transmission coefficients for s and p polarizations vs incident angle

physics.principle: Fresnel equations describe reflection and transmission coefficients at interfaces
details: S and p polarizations have different reflectances
Total internal reflection critical angle exists
At Brewster's angle, p-polarization reflection is zero

experiment.title: Interface Reflection Polarization Measurement
experiment.example: Measuring polarized reflection from glass surface
details: Use rotating analyzer to measure reflection polarization degree
Verify Brewster's angle is about 56.3° for glass
Can precisely determine material refractive index

frontier.title: Anti-Reflection Coatings
details: Use interference to reduce surface reflection
Applied to glasses, solar cells, etc.

brewster.title: Brewster's Angle
brewster.description: The special incident angle where p-polarization reflectance is zero: tan(θB) = n₂/n₁

physics.principle: Brewster's angle is the incident angle where p-polarization reflectance is zero
details: At this angle, reflected light is completely s-polarized
Refracted and reflected rays are perpendicular
For glass, Brewster's angle is about 56.3°

experiment.title: Brewster's Angle Polarization Experiment
experiment.example: Observing polarized reflection from water surface
details: Polarizing filter can eliminate water surface glare

frontier.title: Polarization Photography
details: Underwater photography to reduce surface reflection

chromatic.title: Chromatic Polarization
chromatic.description: Colored interference effect of white light in birefringent materials

physics.principle: Different wavelengths have different phase delays in birefringent materials
details: Color depends on material thickness and birefringence

experiment.title: Polarization Microscope Observation
experiment.example: Observing stress distribution in transparent tape
details: Transparent plastic shows rainbow color bands

frontier.title: Photoelastic Stress Analysis
details: Create transparent models to study stress distribution

opticalRotation.title: Optical Rotation
opticalRotation.description: Chiral substances like sugar solutions rotate the polarization plane

physics.principle: Chiral molecules rotate the polarization plane of linearly polarized light
details: [α] is specific rotation (characteristic of chiral molecule)

experiment.title: Polarimeter Sugar Concentration Measurement
experiment.example: Using polarimeter to determine sugar content
details: Food industry commonly uses this for sugar measurement

frontier.title: Chiral Drug Detection
details: Many drugs have two enantiomeric forms
Different enantiomers may have different effects/toxicity

mieScattering.title: Mie Scattering
mieScattering.description: Scattering characteristics when particle size is comparable to wavelength (white cloud effect)

physics.principle: When particle size is comparable to wavelength, scattering intensity has complex wavelength dependence
details: White clouds appear white due to Mie scattering

rayleigh.title: Rayleigh Scattering
rayleigh.description: Scattering characteristics when particle size is much smaller than wavelength (blue sky effect)

physics.principle: When particle size is much smaller than wavelength, scattering intensity is proportional to λ⁻⁴
details: Short wavelength (blue light) scatters more strongly
This is why the sky appears blue
Red sunset is because blue light is scattered away

experiment.title: Blue Sky Experiment
experiment.example: Adding small amount of milk to water to simulate

stokes.title: Stokes Vector
stokes.description: Four parameters to completely describe light's polarization state

physics.principle: Stokes vector uses four parameters to completely describe polarization state
details: S₃: Right vs left circular polarization

experiment.title: Stokes Parameter Measurement
experiment.example: Four measurements to determine polarization state
details: Combined with wave plate to measure circular component

mueller.title: Mueller Matrix
mueller.description: 4×4 matrix describing optical element's transformation of polarization state

physics.principle: Mueller matrix describes an optical element's transformation of polarization state

experiment.title: Optical Element Mueller Matrix Measurement
experiment.example: Measuring Mueller matrix of a polarizer

basics.title: Optical Basics
basics.description: Fundamental concepts of light and electromagnetic waves

lightWave.title: Light as Electromagnetic Wave
lightWave.description: Understanding light as transverse electromagnetic waves

physics.principle: Light is a transverse electromagnetic wave with oscillating electric and magnetic fields perpendicular to propagation direction
details: Electric and magnetic fields oscillate perpendicular to each other
Light travels at c = 3×10⁸ m/s in vacuum
Wavelength determines color (400-700nm for visible light)

polarizationIntro.title: What is Polarization?
polarizationIntro.description: Introduction to the concept of light polarization

physics.principle: Polarization describes the orientation of the electric field oscillation in a light wave
details: Unpolarized light has random electric field orientations
Polarized light has a definite oscillation pattern
Types: linear, circular, and elliptical polarization

polarizationTypes.title: Types of Polarization
polarizationTypes.description: Linear, circular, and elliptical polarization explained

physics.principle: Different polarization types arise from the phase and amplitude relationship of orthogonal field components
details: Linear: E-field oscillates in a single plane
Circular: E-field rotates with constant magnitude
Elliptical: E-field traces an ellipse (most general case)
